President Muller has imposed

Successor to Dean of SAIS sought
By ALLEN SHORT
The Search Committee
appointed to recommend a
successor to retiring Dean Francis
0. Wilcox of the School of
Advanced International Studies
(SAIS) has announced plans for
immediate action.
The first meeting of the
committee will be held next.
week, according to University
Provost Dr. Harry Woolf. who
has been appointed committee
chairman by President Muller.
Already under consideration is
a list of some 30 names. Woolf
expects the field of candidates to
grow as the search continues, and

added that "Of course there are
always 'in-house' candidates in
such situations, and we have a
few."
"The sooner the decision, the
better," he continued, explaining
that although the committee has
no set date by which to propose
a candidate to the Board of
Trustees, both for SAIS . and
Hopkins. it is desirable to have
an early decision for planning
purposes.
The fourteen -member
committee includes University
Trustee Alfred D. Chandler, Jr..
National Security Council
member Helmut Sonnenfeldt.

and Homewood professor of
political science Robert W.
Tucker.
Dean Wilcox's retirement is to
be effective September-1, 1973,
in compliance with the
University policy of mandatory
retirement at age 65.
In recognition of the Dean's
outstanding service to the
University, the Board of Trustees
has designated Wilcox Dean
Emeritus of SAIS.
The School was founded in
1944 by Christian A. Herter, who
later became Secretary of State
in the Eisenhower

Changed all that. Most

He continued to describe
briefly the art of leadership as a
technique, a waiting for a

Spent a long time developing
some of the ideas in it. Fifteen
Years later, as he begins his
second year as President of
Hopkins, some of them are still
evident in what he does and what
he says.
He is still willing to take risks,
to do what has not been done
before and to lead, not by force,

action.

Worthwhile fundraising, and no

n on-academic life of students. No
°Ile administrator was

aoministration of the Homewood
campus and oddly, no
undergraduate had ever been a

assuming the presidency, Muller
Changed all that. Most
I mportantly, last October, her
Proposed to the Board of

Williamsburg, Va., that Hopkins
u ndertake a $200 million
centennial capital campaign,
I ncluding 100 endowed

the University to ask for one
.hundred endowed positions for
Its faculty will be a dramatic

challenge, and one that will once
more turn the eyes of not only
our own community , but of the

something on a scale no other
university in this country, or for

attempted to do before." The
campaign, which is expected to
take several years to complete,
will be announced formally at
Commemoration Day February
22nd.

university president, Muller has
not spent all his time on it during
his first year. He has spent
considerable time dealing with
administrative problems both in
the University and in the
Hospital, of which he became
President on October 1st.

of the key recommendations of
last year's Blue Ribbon Panel on

reviving the position of Dean of

collegiate version of a high school

Wrestlers disconsolate after Lebanon bout
By BARRY KEMELHOR
The Johns Hopkins wrestling
team dropped a hard fought 18 16 decision to Lebanon Valley
last night at Hopkins The close
defeat was all the more
disappointing, due to some
questionable officiating and
narrow decisions.
Since intercollegiate wrestling
is scored on the basis of 2 points
for a draw; 3 points for a
decision (4 for a win by 10 or
more points); and 6 points per

win, the Blue Jays could have
come away the victors merely by
tying one more match. As
150-pounder Greg Goldman
commented,"We should've won."
Successful grapplers for
Hopkins were 134-pounder Clark
Kingery, who romped to a 13-7
win=highlighted by 3 takedowns;
142-pounder Rob Fink, a 13-4
victor with 3 near pins; Craig
Stevens with 5 minutes of riding
time and a 6-0 whitewash in the
167 pound class;undefeated 190

pound junior Neil Hazard, who
destroyed highly-touted Clarion
State transfer Steve Sank, 14-5;
and freshman heavyweight Gary
Murza, who rolled to a 16-3 win.
The losses were more difficult
to swallow and much more
closely contested-especially in
the 158 pound class. In that
division, freshman Dave Myrlock
had a commanding 6-2 lead and
was in complete control against
Lebanon Valley co-captain Doren
Leathers, only to slip up for an

instant and allow himself to be
pinned. Almost as frustrating
were Mike Priviterra's 7-6 riding
time defeat in the 126 pound
class, and Greg Goldman's
narrow 9-7 loss to 10 pounder
Guy Lesser, whom Greg
described as "a professional
staller" . Other vanquished Blue
Jays were Ron Pucillo, a 7-3 loser
in the 118 pound category, and
177 pound Wayne Panullo, who
dropped an 8-2 decision to Alan
Shortell-the only wrestler to

defeat Neil Hazard last year.
Ashamed
All in all, Hopkins won five
of the ten matches, but was
edged on points. However, the
margin was considerably closer
than last year's 24-18 loss at
Lebanon Valley, and the Jay
grapplers have nothing to be
ashamed of. Their 1972-73
record now stands at a still
respectable 6-2, and they hope to
add to that mark next Saturday
at Towson State.

Animal group attacks Hopkins' Professor Ray
By ROBERT PAULUS
Strong opposition to the participation
of Dr. Carleton Ray, Hopkins Professor
of Pathobiology, in the Marine Mammal
Commision or its Scientific Advisory
Committee has developed both in the
private and public lobbying efforts of
The Fund for Animals, Inc.
The Fund for Animals, Inc., a
conservationist group which opposes the
killing of all marine mammals, has
attacked Ray for alleged lobbying in
support of a weak marine mammal
protection bill which would continue the
killing of such mammals and for his
alleged view that such animals should be
managed on a maximum or optimum
"sustained yield" basis.
The conservationist group is extremely
distressed with the possibility that Ray
may be selected as a scientific advisor to
the Marine Mammal Commission, which
was created under the terms of the
Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972.
While Ray's name was not among the
list of five names submitted to President
Nixon for appointment to the
Commission, a high ranking member of
The Fund for Animals commented:
"Unofficially we have been told that it
will be very hard to keep him off the
Commission's Advisory Committee."
It was originally thought that Ray,
who is Program Director of the
Smithsonian's Marine Mammal Council,
would be nominated for the $30,000 a
year commissioner job.
In a November 2, 1972 letter to Russel
Train, Chairman of the Council on
Environmental Quality, The Fund for
Animals opposed the appointment of
Ray and Dr. Kenneth Norris and William
Schevill, both of the Smithsonian's
Marine Mammal Council.
Ray has vehemently denied having any
interest in the Commission. In a
December 19, 1971 story in the
Baltimore Sun Ray stated that he would
not accept the new job if it were
offered." He has stated however, that he
would be willing to serve as a scientific
advisor.
In the letter to Russell Train, Lewis
Regenstein, National Coordinator of the
Fund for Animals charged that Ray may
have been responsible for the creation of
the Commission and therefore, that his
involvement in the Commission would be

a case of "political pork barreling."
When asked about the Commission,
Ray said, "I won't tell you where it came
from but it didn't come from me. But I
think it's a damn good idea."
Ray stated that he originally became
involved with the Mammal Protection Bill
as a result of a request by Representative
John D. Dingell (D. Mich.) , chairman of
the House wildlife sub-committee."I was
asked from the beginning because they
saw there was alot of pressure which
wasn't rational so they asked us (Ray,
Norris, and Schevill of the Smithsonian)
to help design a bill."
Ray has labeled the Fund for Animals
group as "extremists." "They are in the
same league as the anti-vivisectionists.
These people basically would like to
protect all marine mammals and are
opposed to all slaughter of marine
mammals, including killing for game

let ter calls Ray's "obcession wwith

House Merchant Marine and Fisheries

rewritten.

flagrant exemption to the ban on imports

fur industry. He also stated that the bill

seal skins and finished products for sale
in the U'S', even during the moratorium
period during which time all other
products are effectively banned."

retired research biologist of the Scripps
Institute of Oceanography. _

International Whaling Commission, would

Commission. In testimony offered before

June 1971, Chapman unsuccessfully
opposed the resolutions calling for a
moratorium on whaling. Regenstein's

muster. Conservation must not remain a
house divided."
